column1: Some improvements have recently been made by Mr. Alexander Glegg and the inventor in the well-known Jamieson grapnel
column2: used for raising submerged submarine cables. The chief feature of the grapnel is that the flukes
column4: bend back against a spring when they catch a rock
column5: until the grapnel clears the obstruction
column6: but allow the cable to run home to the crutch between the fluke and base. In the older form the cable was liable to get jammed
column7: and cut between the fixed toe or fluke and the longer fluke jointed into it. This is now avoided by embracing the short fluke within the longer one. The shank
column9: is now pushed through and kept up against the collar of the boss
column11: which at the same time presses back the hinged flukes after being displaced by a rock. The shank can now freely swivel round
column12: whereas before it was rigidly fixed. The toes or flukes are now made of soft cast steel
column13: which can be straightened if bent
column14: and the boss is made of cast steel or gun-metal.
